dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW MARSH lies on his back in bed.  He is a frail-look man in his early sixties, with thinning gray hair.  On to him is a much younger WOMAN.  Although her back is to us, catch flashes of her face for a moment as she turns from to side.  We see enough to know that this is a beautiful She moves wildly, grinding her hips into him, her head ar back, her hands rubbing lightly over her breasts.  She re down, grabbing his hips and jerks them upwards, forcing h deeper inside her.  They move together -- faster -- and f The CAMERA slowly begins to PULL BACK.  As it does we see we are watching is on a TELEVISION. Further back still.  We see TWO UNIFORMED POLICE OFFICERS standing before the television watching the act. The CAMERA begins to pan around the room.  Rain streaks d the windows of the room -- LIGHTNING flashes outside.  A CAMERA is set up on a tripod.  More PLAIN CLOTHES POLICE, looking, dusting, talking. We continue to PAN.  We can now see it is the same room o tape.  ON the bed lies the naked body of ANDREW MARSH, a covering his lower torso.  His face is ashen, mouth open, dull eyes looking out in a fixed stare.  The last instant his life is etched upon a face frozen in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHTNING fills the night sky.  THUNDER BOOMS overhead. wind whips the RAIN furiously against anything in its pat The CAMERA moves slowly along rows of beautiful HOMES.  A end is a cul-de-sac.  Several POLICE CARS are in the driv their RED LIGHTS FLASHING. A four-door SEDAN pulls into the driveway.  JOHN CARDENAS out into the rain.  He is a handsome Latin in his thirtie with hard, chiseled features and black, slicked-backed ha He does not run through the rain -- he walks. DETECTIVE REESE, a man who looks more like an accountant homicide detective runs out to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it Marsh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just a hint of sadness shows on Cardenas' face.  It lasts instant, then it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, do you mind if we get out of the rain? Cardenas doesn't move.  He ignores the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Secretary.  Joanne Braslow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  She stopped by to pick up some papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me. Reese starts for the house.  Cardenas looks up into the n sky.  A FLASH of LIGHTNING fills the SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: Pull back to reveal a POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER snapping pictur Marsh in bed. Cardenas enters followed by Reese.  He moves through the FORENSIC and MEDICAL TEAMS.  Anything Cardenas feels abou gruesome sight before him is hidden behind a mask of indifference. Standing by the bed is ASSISTANT DISTRICT ATTORNEY, ROGER TROXELL, a short, baby-faced man.  Cardenas looks down at body, then over at the MEDICAL EXAMINER, DR. HENRY McCURD portly man with windblown cheeks and bloodshot eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sure.  I'll have everything you need tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at this. Reese points to the nightstand drawer and Troxell opens i top of the nightstand is a box of tissues and a bottle of spray.  Inside are ROPES, HANDCUFFS and an assortment of AIDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy was into some kinky shit. Cardenas looks at the various sexual devices, then walks the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNE BRASLOW sits on chair.  Her eyes are tired -- red crying.  She is mid thirties -- attractive, but her looks more from effort than nature -- expensive hair cut -- the cosmetics.  She has a corporate look to her. Cardenas steps into the hall and walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Braslow -- I'm District Attorney John Cardenas.  You arrived at what time tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little after eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had some papers to pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who Mr. Marsh was with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know her address, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- but I can get it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas walks down the corridor with McCurdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh wasn't alone.  We found traces of sperm on the sheets.  The toxicology report says there were high levels of cocaine in his blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he die of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official cause of death was a cardiac arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what my report will read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach a door and stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's speculative at this point. Marsh had advanced Arterial disease. His heart attack was induced by excessive aerobic activity -- in conjunction with the drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCurdy enters the room.  Cardenas thinks for a moment, t follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spacious and sparsely furnished.  The walls are empty.  N commendations, plaques or photographs to add prestige to office.  Cardenas steps into the room and looks at McCurd is already seated next to Reese and Troxell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McCurdy) What are you saying, Henry?  That his girlfriend fucked him to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trace of a grin shows on Cardenas' face.  He walks over the window and stares outside.  Reese, Troxell and McCurd as he thinks.  A beat.  Cardenas turns back to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we prove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know Marsh had a head cold.   We found cocaine mixed with water in a nasal spray container on the nightstand.  The coke would contract the nasal membrane the same as any decongestant, but for a much shorter time.  He'd keep using more and more -- never knowing what he was taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any prints on the nasal spray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh's and Rebecca Lawson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he did know what was in it? A lot of users put it in nasal spray bottles so they can use it in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocaine is the last thing a man in his condition would want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we put Rebecca Lawson at the scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man across the street from Marsh saw her drive up about four thirty Sunday afternoon.  And her prints are all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas stands and walks to a DART BOARD on the wall.  H gathers the DARTS, moves back and tosses one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh's Cardiologist told me that after Marsh was diagnosed with heart disease he quit smoking, quit drinking and started exercising every day.  Does that sound like a guy who'd start shoveling cocaine up his nose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say about Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can remember at least one occasion -- and the receptionist can recall two times when she accompanied Marsh to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas throws another dart at the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she knew about his heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to.  I also interviewed three women who were in past relationships with Marsh.  There's no evidence that he had anything but straight sex prior to meeting Miss Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best part.  She gets it all -- everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray clouds hang over head.  A light drizzle falls.  A GR MOURNERS hold umbrellas as they stand around the grave. In the b.g. the PRESS is visible, held back my private SE GUARDS. A WOMAN dressed in BLACK stands in the front of the MOUNE her face hidden behind a hat and veil.  RAYMOND SATTLER, tall, distinguished-looking man in his sixties stands bes her.  He supports his weight with the aid of a CANE.  The service concludes.  Sattler along with several other PEOP offer her their condolences.  Joanne Braslow is there.  S does not go over to Rebecca. CARDENAS AND REESE stand off to the side by a large oak t Cardenas watches and waits.  He steps forward as Sattler the woman by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman stops.  Her back is to Cardenas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm District Attorney, John Cardenas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA LAWSON removes her hat and veil and slowly turns around.  She is in her late twenties.  A deep pain fills face -- controlled, but evident.  Her eyes are tired -- h from crying -- but no tears show now.  This is a woman wh grief is private and not displayed for others.  Although emotionally drained she is still stunningly beautiful.  S beautiful that even Cardenas' usually cool demeanor canno how impressed he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that this is the time, or the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to introduce myself and inform Miss Lawson that there will be an inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inquiry into what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For starters I'd like to know why she left the house and didn't report the death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he wasn't dead when she left, and even if he was, not reporting a natural death in a timely fashion isn't a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say it was a natural death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas and Rebecca lock eyes.  Rebecca stares at him genuinely shocked by his accusation.  Cardenas nods and w away.  In the b.g. we see Joanne staring at Rebecca with hostility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large and homey.  A fire roars in the fireplace.  FRANK D sits on his couch as he goes over some PAPERWORK.  He is thirties, powerful, self-assured. SHARON DULANEY enters.  She is an attractive woman in her thirties.  She kisses him on the cheek then pushes his PAPERWORK aside and sits down on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on vacation, remember?  You're supposed to be relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing the papers aside) This is not relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) And I suppose you're going to show me how to relax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want me to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always open to learning new things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him -- soft, gentle kisses.  Dulaney puts his around her and kisses her harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to see what you mean. Why don't we go upstairs and work on the advanced course?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  I've got to finish a counter offer on the Bergman property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is passing by.  A trace of frustration shows o Dulaney's face -- this is obviously not a new occurrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't it wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- it has to be done by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is gone.  Dulaney forces an understanding smil looks towards the door and sees his EIGHT YEAR OLD SON, MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Slugger.  Ready for bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael walks over to this parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.  Dulaney answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?... Hi Raymond.... What?... Well, I was sort of planning on... Alright... Okay, goodbye. (hangs up; to Sharon) That was Sattler.  He thinks the D.A.'s going to file on Rebecca Lawson.  He wants me in the office tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to go to the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  What can I do?  He is the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could let you have your vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad -- is it true what they're saying about that Miss Lawson Lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids at school say she humped Mr. Marsh to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know better than that.  What did I teach you to say when someone is accused of doing something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She allegedly humped him to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney grins.  Sharon is fighting the temptation to laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear -- the both of you. (to Dulaney) Some example you set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating her) Some example you set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a funny face at Michael who LAUGHS and makes one Dulaney grabs him and starts TICKLING him.  Michael SCREA with LAUGHTER as he tries to tickle him back.  Dulaney th starts TICKLING SHARON -- Michael helps him.  Sharon ROAR LAUGHTER and falls to the floor.  The three of them roll LAUGHING hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sattler sits on a couch sipping a cup of coffee.  Dulaney across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew Marsh was a very wealthy man. A trial like this is going to put Cardenas in the spot-light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already got press arriving from over the country and she hasn't even been charged yet. Cardenas wants to see her in his office tomorrow at ten.  I'd like you to go with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- but she wants you to represent her if Cardenas files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I told her you were the best criminal attorney we have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond, I'm the only criminal attorney you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jokingly) Well, I guess that makes you the best. (candidly) Look, Frank -- she stands to inherit three million dollars.  As executors of the estate and her attorneys that could generate a lot of legal fees for us.  All I'm asking you to do is talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney thinks about it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll talk to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's waiting in the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney stands and walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know, I knew Andrew Marsh for almost twenty years -- or thought I did.  What do you think would make a man in his condition do the things he did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney stops at the door and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the question is:  What is it about her that made him want to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is seated at the end of the conference table smok CIGARETTE.  Sunlight flows through a window and highlight hair.  She is dressed in a fashionable business suit that clings to every curve of her body. Dulaney enters the room.  When he sees her he can't help stare.  Rebecca notes his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lawson, I'm Frank Dulaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises the cigarette to her lips.  Dulaney notices de her outward composure her hand is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Are you going to represent me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no charges against you. I'm here to decide if I'm going to represent you should that occur. (beat) Did you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca appears hurt by the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't waste any time, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney doesn't answer.  He studies her -- his eyes probi hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you think I did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  That's why I'm asking you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have some feeling.  Some immediate impression.  A young, attractive woman, involved with an older man who leaves her everything in his will.  And the things that went on in that house.  Such wild sex.  What kind of picture does that paint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a very good one I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's exactly what the jury will see when they look at me.  That's why I need a very good lawyer, Mr. Dulaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're assuming the District Attorney is going to file charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca's anxiety begins to surface.  She feigns a weak s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll file.  He's an ambitious man. Ambitious men build their careers on the bodies of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still haven't answered my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a long drag of her cigarette before answering. looks at Dulaney.  Displaying emotions is not something t comes easily.  Tears well up in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionally) I loved him.  A big part of my life has been torn away from me, Mr. Dulaney.  A part I can never get back -- and on top of that people are saying that I am somehow responsible for it.  They've taken everything that is good and caring about two people in love and made it dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single tear streams down her check.  She knows what he to hear her say -- and she resents having to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I didn't kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas walks down the hall, sipping a cup of coffee.  T walks towards him excitedly.  They walk together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to make your day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troxell points to an Office.  Through the glass partition can see a MAN sitting at a table.  ALAN PALEY is a well-g man in his thirties who makes every effort to look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got this guy in my office. Doctor Alan Paley.  Wait until you hear what he has to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas and Troxell enters the room.  Cardenas shakes ha with Paley and listens with great interest as he starts t talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney and Sharon are in bed.  Dulaney reads some PAPERS Sharon finishes reading her MAGAZINE.  She puts it on the nightstand and looks at Dulaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can Cardenas possibly think he can build a case against two consenting adults?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have something or he wouldn't be pressing so hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he files are you going to take the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.  I want to hear what she says at her statement tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attractive.  Bright.  Distant. Charming when she wants to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney's description seems to bother her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sounds like quite a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) Yeah -- but can she cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon hits him on the arm playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing gives me the creeps. I mean -- what if she really humped him to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney grins at her choice of words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humped

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can think of worse ways to go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney rolls over, gathering her up in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) --and speaking of humping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches over to the nightstand and turns off the LIGHT

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CITY HALL BUILDING MORNING
dialogues.text: As Dulaney and Rebecca walks up the steps they are engulf a CROWD of REPORTERS.  Dulaney puts his arm around Rebecc ushers her through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney and Rebecca sit on one side of a table.  Reese st Cardenas sits at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know that Andrew was dead until Mr. Sattler called me at home that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a witness who saw you go into the house at four thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not denying she was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did you leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six thirty -- and he was very much alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lawson, do you use cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you use it the night Marsh died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I haven't done it in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Marsh use it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had to get there somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't get there from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you aware of Mr. Marsh's heart condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Marsh's Cardiologist and his nurse have told us that you accompanied Mr. Marsh to their office on at least two occasions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct -- but Andrew never told me he had a heart condition.  He said he had a heart arrhythmia and it was nothing serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never mentioned his heart disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think he lied to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's something only Marsh would know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Miss Lawson knew it too.  I think she slipped him the coke and he popped his cork giving her the high- hard-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney's anger shows.  He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.  My client doesn't have to take this crap from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Miss Lawson came in here voluntarily to answer your questions. She doesn't have to sit here and be insulted.  So, either you charge her now or we're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Dulaney and Cardenas lock eyes.  Cardenas shrugs shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney motions for Rebecca to get up.  She stands and th walk to the door.  Reese looks at Cardenas.  Cardenas nod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca Lawson, you're under arrest for the murder of Andrew Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is stunned -- frightened.  She looks at Dulaney i disbelief.  Dulaney looks at Cardenas angrily.  Reese rem his handcuffs as he moves towards Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to remain silent. If you give up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Reese) I don't think the handcuffs will be necessary.  You can finish giving Miss Lawson her rights outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese grabs Rebecca by the arm and leads her to the door. looks back at Frank, her face filled with fear -- her eye welling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have you out in a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese ushers her through the door.  A beat.  Dulaney and Cardenas are left alone.  Cardenas starts fishing through of NUTS, carefully extracting the cashews.  Dulaney conti to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin' to make the papers, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh left her close to three million dollars in his will.  That's motive. She admits to being there the night of his death.  That's opportunity -- and her fingerprints are on the nasal spray bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You can't show intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas looks at Dulaney wryly.  He knows that Dulaney i trying to discover his game plan.  Cardenas looks into hi of nuts and fishes for another cashew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your pole out of the water, Frank.  The fish ain't biting today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bluffing.  John, it's me, remember?  I've known you since your name was Juan Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas doesn't appreciate Dulaney mentioning his real n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) C'mon -- think about it.  If she was going to kill Marsh why leave the nasal spray bottle there for the police to find?

dialogues.text: She planned this.  She wanted us to find the nasal spray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would she want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's clever.  Because she knows that even if we didn't find it we'd have suspicions as to why a man in Marsh's condition would use cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suspicions maybe -- but suspicions aren't enough for a conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The M.E.'s report stated that Marsh's nasal membranes showed no sign of prior cocaine use.  Without the nasal spray we would have still treated it as a poisoning.  We would have looked for motive and the trail would have still led back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy it and neither will a jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going all the way on this one, Frank.  Tell your client she has until the prelim to cop a plea for murder two -- fifteen to twenty five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell her but she won't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she's not as smart as I thought she was.  You've seen her in the depositions.  Tell me you don't have any doubts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Well -- we'll let the blindfolded lady with the scales decide that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney gets up slowly and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney waits at the counter.  A barred door slides open Rebecca is led out by a WOMAN JAILER.  Even in these surroundings she maintains her composure.  She walks to t counter and waits silently.

dialogues.text: As Dulaney and Rebecca leave they are once again encircle REPORTERS, screaming questions, asking them to verify Reb arrest.  Dulaney plows through the crowd with Rebecca in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray clouds hang overhead, threatening rain.  Tall birch line the river, the color of their leaves hinting that au is approaching.  Dulaney and Rebecca walk along a jogging cut along the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know right now that the trial's going to be nasty.  Your sex life is going to be dragged through the mud.  They're going to say that you enticed Marsh -- led him down a dark path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew hardly needed leading.  He was a very passionate man.  He was eager to explore.  I gave him what he wanted.  We fulfilled each others needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very small town -- people here have very straight views on sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm used to being on the outside looking in.  The same men who will publicly profess their moral outrage for my sexual tastes are the same ones who privately rest their sweaty little hands on my legs and talk about weekend trips together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those same men will be sitting on the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am who I am.  I can't deny it, anymore than you can deny who you are.  I like sex different -- I like it wild.  That's not a crime. (emotional) I loved Andrew.  We made love together.  We made it differently, but we still made love.  It was our way.  It was private -- and now the whole world wants to look in through the pretense of justice.  If I was some middle-aged divorcee who screwed him once a week do you think this would be happening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops walking and stares out over the River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen animals make love, Mr. Dulaney?  They have such passion -- such savage emotion.  They struggle, and snarl, and claw, but neither hurts the other.  Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pain, no gain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rebecca speaks, Dulaney seems captivated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we are.  Our primal urges are still there -- but we've taken sex and intellectualized it, refined it down to its most essential components.  It's bland, easy, mechanical.  There's great passion in the struggle -- such craving in denial.  Do you know what it's like to yearn for something?  I'm not talking about wanting, or needing. I'm talking about an urge so deep that your skin burns and every cell in your body pulses with desire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney appears moved by the passion of her words -- but uncomfortable by it and quickly pushes it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) I think we're getting a little off the subject here.

dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try.

dialogues.text: Rebecca thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was growing up we had a strawberry patch in our backyard. So did this family down the road.  I used to sneak in their yard and steal their strawberries.  It wasn't easy. The stone walls were high and I'd scrape my knees as I climbed over. On the other side were wild rose bushes.  The thorns would dig into my legs and cut my thighs as I lowered myself down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney appears lost in her words.  This isn't lost on Re She walks off.  Dulaney stares after her intrigued.

dialogues.text: Dark.  Sharon is asleep.  The door opens and Dulaney ente quietly.  He walks towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney splashes a handful of water across his face.  He unbuttons his shirt and takes it off -- wincing as he doe turns his back to the mirror.  Several deep FINGERNAIL SC are dug into his back.  He looks at himself in the mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney and Biggs walk down the hall to a water cooler. pours himself a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you ask there's nothing new on the coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to get me something I can use, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sattler walks over with another MAN.  He ignores Biggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank -- this is Harvey Willows from the L.A. Times.  He'd like to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an incredible story going on here. (as if quoting a headline) Woman accused of using sex to kill lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say -- it's gonna give a whole new meaning to the state nickname.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biggs LAUGHS and walks off.  Sattler glares at him.  Dula smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What's the state nickname?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) The Beaver State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of new Town Houses line the street.  Dulaney drives walks towards the front door of one of them.  He KNOCKS. JOANNE BRASLOW answers.  She stares at Dulaney innocently

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparsely decorated.  Very trendy.  High tech furniture an designer lights.  Joanne sits on the couch -- Dulaney on the chairs.  There is COFFEE on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worked for Mr. Marsh for six years. He was a good man -- until she came along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What changed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did.  Look, I know you can lead a horse to water but you can't make him drink -- but you hold a pail of water in front of an old horse for long enough  -- and well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanne stops as emotion fills her.  Her eyes well with te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really believe what the district attorney is saying about Miss Lawson, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It's incredible to think that anyone could be capable of doing that -- but if anyone could it would be Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you don't like Miss Lawson very much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know her that well. We would say hello to each other when I would come to the house, but that was about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't know her that well what makes you think she's capable of murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew was a kind and gentle man, but he was thirty years older than her. Where's the attraction to sleep with someone like that -- to have the kind of sex they had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know what kind of sex they had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't lookin' through the keyhole if that's what you're thinking.  I'd come to house sometimes to pick up papers or speak to Andrew.  I'd find their little toys all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Marsh use drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney is shocked by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at the house one morning -- I thought Miss Lawson was upstairs with Mr. Marsh.  When I went into the guest bathroom she was standing in front of the mirror pouring this white powder out of a vial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney looks like he's been kicked in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Dulaney looks at her slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  No -- nothing.  Thank you for your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and walks to the door.  Joanne stands and star after him with a trace of a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca opens the front door and Dulaney barges into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just left Joanne Braslow.  She told me she saw you doing cocaine at Marsh's house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yelling) That's not good enough, Goddamit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't true.  You have to believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't have to believe you.  The jury has to believe you and answers like he's lying or she's mistaken aren't going to convince them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't use cocaine anymore.  If she says she saw me doing it she's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would she lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Frank -- but don't you think that's something we should find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney is confused, struggling to decide if he believes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon is getting a load of washing ready.  She picks up Dulaney's tee shirts and notices several thin stripes of near the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN falls.  Dulaney enters the room to find Michael on t PHONE.  Dulaney appears nervous -- anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael -- get off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Because I'm expecting a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- But it's Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) I know what day it is!  Get off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt; into phone) I gotta go.  I'll call you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael hangs up and leaves the room.  Dulaney stares at phone -- struggling against himself.  He picks it up and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Rebecca Lawson.  I'm not in right now.  So if you please leave a message--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney slams down the phone.  He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney wears another tee shirt as he sleeps.  Sharon is staring up at the ceiling.  A beat.  She rolls over and carefully lifts up Dulaney's tee shirt.  She sees the scr on his back.  She does not wake him.  She just lays there in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca walks down the hall.  In the b.g. we see Dulaney walking quickly to join her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called you all weekend.  Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went out on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gallery is crowded with REPORTERS and SPECTATORS.  Du sits beside Rebecca at the defense table.  Cardenas stand before the jury. Dulaney and Cardenas are seated at their respective table Rebecca sits beside Dulaney.  She is wearing a beautiful, tailored dress.  She looks beautiful and has surprisingly no attempt to down-play her looks. JUDGE BURNHAM, a confident BLACK MAN in his fifties sits the bench.  He is strong-willed -- tough but fair.  There rough edge to him from his childhood on the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This trial by its very nature is explosive.  The press is going to have a field day and I will not tolerate any activity in my courtroom that will fuel it. (to Dulaney and Cardenas) Both of you are going to be delving into very personal aspects of peoples lives.  I warn you now.  When you do so -- if you cannot establish a clear line of relevancy early on in your examinations I will stop you.  Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney and Cardenas both nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cardenas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas stands and walks towards the JURY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to Rebecca) You all can see the defendant, Rebecca Lawson.  But as this trial proceeds you will see that she is not only the defendant -- she is the murder weapon itself. (stops and thinks for a moment) Is that possible?  Can a person actually be a weapon?  The answer is yes.  If I hit you and you die -- I am the cause of your death.  But can sex be called a weapon?  Yes.  And what a deadly weapon Rebecca Lawson made of it.  The State will prove that Miss Lawson seduced Andrew Marsh -- that she put increasing sexual demands on him while she secretly administered cocaine.  All the while knowing that he had a severe heart condition. (beat) She is a beautiful woman -- but when this trial is over you will see her no differently than a gun, or a knife or any other instrument used as a weapon.  She is a killer.  And the worst kind -- one who disguised herself as a loving partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas walks back to the prosecution table and sits dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dulaney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney stands up and approaches the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're thinking -- and it's a mistake.  You look at Miss Lawson and you see a beautiful woman who was involved with an older man -- and you think she looks like the type.  She could've done it.  And that's exactly what the District Attorney wants you to think.  Yes, she is beautiful.  So what?  Does that make her a killer?  Of course not.  This case is not about appearances.  It's about facts. (beat) As Mr. Cardenas presents his case you will see that there are very few facts -- that the bulk of the States evidence is circumstantial.  I'm confident that by the conclusion of this trial you will not just have a reasonable doubt.  You will have no doubt at all --  that Rebecca Lawson is innocent of the charges against her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCurdy is on the witness stand.  Cardenas stands before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor McCurdy, what was the cause of death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive cardiac arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was Mr. Marsh's physical condition prior to his death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very poor.  He was suffering from severe arterial disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the heart attack the result of natural causes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What induced it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found a high concentration of cocaine in his blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Marsh used cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  The membrane in his nasal passage didn't show any sign of long time usage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how did it get into his body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found a bottle of Dristan nasal spray on the nightstand.  It was filled with water and cocaine.  Mr. Marsh had a head cold at the time of his death.  I believe he wasn't aware that he was ingesting cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas holds up a bottle of NASAL SPRAY in a PLASTIC BA brings it over to McCurdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the bottle that was found on the nightstand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examines it) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the State enters this evidence as exhibit A. (to McCurdy) Were any fingerprints found on the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- those of Mr. Marsh and a thumb print of Miss Lawson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. McCurdy, what would cocaine do to someone in Mr. Marsh's condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Increase his heart rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And if he were in the midst of making love while under the influence of cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be an added stress to his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would be the effect if someone secretly administered cocaine to Mr. Marsh and then induced him to make love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be the same as shooting a gun at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor McCurdy. (to Dulaney) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca looks at Dulaney for his opinion of McCurdy's testimony.  Dulaney gives her a reassuring glance before stands up and approaches McCurdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you say with any certainty that Mr. Marsh didn't ingest the cocaine himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- but it seems highly unlikely that a man in his condition would use cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your opinion, Doctor -- but I'm asking you if there is any scientific test that can tell who actually put the cocaine into the Dristan bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas stands before DOCTOR TRAMMEL, a thin, pasty-face in his fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Trammel, when did you first diagnose that Mr. Marsh had heart disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a year and half ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Marsh change his lifestyle after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- he stopped smoking and drinking and exercised regularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did everything he could to take care of his heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Miss Lawson ever accompany Mr. Marsh to your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one last question.  What does the sign on your office door say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Steven Trammel.  Cardiologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas walks back to his seat, signaling his examinatio the witness is over.  Dulaney stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Trammel, did you ever speak to Miss Lawson about Mr. Marsh's condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Marsh ever tell you that he had spoken to Miss Lawson about his illness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Miss Lawson ever accompany Mr. Marsh inside during his examinations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have no way of knowing what Mr. Marsh told Miss Lawson were the reasons for his visits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanne Braslow is on the stand.  She is wearing a smart business suit and large-framed glasses.  Her hair is pull back tight.  Cardenas stands before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you Mr Marsh's personal secretary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see Mr. Marsh use Cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the court about that, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I opened the bathroom door one day and saw Miss Lawson pouring Cocaine out of a vial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Mr. Marsh the day before his death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrible.  He was tired and pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you talk about Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Mr. Marsh say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was worried.  He said that she was acting stranger and stranger.  He said that if this kept up she was going to kill him.  That his heart couldn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an audible BUZZ from the crowd.  For the first t Rebecca's confident exterior seems to fade and is replace genuine concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Dulaney) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas sits down.  Dulaney gets up slowly and walks tow Joanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know it was cocaine that Miss Lawson had in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other kind of white powder do people keep in a vial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the date when you saw Miss Lawson in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes-- (thinks a moment) It was on a Friday.  I remember because I was going to visit my sister for her birthday.  It would be October twenty-eighth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you repeat the last part of what Mr. Marsh said to you the day before his death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that if it kept up she was going to kill him.  That his heart couldn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Mr. Marsh also tell you that Miss Lawson felt bored here and was thinking about going back to Chicago for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- he mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the woman he loved passionately was thinking about leaving.  That must cause tremendous anxiety. Sleepless nights.  Incredible stress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, isn't it possible that he was confiding in you about the pain he was feeling about losing what might be his last chance for love?  That what he really was saying was that the uncertainty of her leaving was driving him crazy and if it didn't stop it was going to kill him.  That if she did leave his heart couldn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE JURY waits anxiously for her answer. Joanne fidgets in his chair as she thinks.  She appears confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, think about it.  Isn't it possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly) Yes.  I suppose it's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas leans back in his seat frustrated.  Rebecca brea sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet and desolate -- most of the city employees have lef the day.  Dulaney walks towards the back of the lot with Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were brilliant today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strong endings start with strong beginnings. (growing excitement) I love the way you twist what people say around --  manipulating their own words against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach Rebecca's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see you later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca presses against him, raising her knee gently into groin -- as she kisses him passionately.  Dulaney is lost her kiss for a moment, then breaks it off and looks aroun Rebecca smiles -- takes off her shoes and stands on the h her car.  She takes one of the shoes and hits the PARKING OVERHEAD LIGHT FIXTURE.  The BULB breaks sending the area darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps down and kisses him again.  For a moment he tri resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you inside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His desire fills him.  He pushes her back onto the hood o car, hiking up her dress with his hands, as she reaches d and unbuttons his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dimly lit.  Dulaney is in bed.  He appears to deep in thought.  Rebecca enters wearing a sheer, silk ba and carrying a tea service on a tray.  He places it on th and sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paley could be a problem tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll be able to handle him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you have such confidence in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Paley.  He can't touch me.  No one can.  I've thought it all out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits up; very concerned) What does that mean?  You've been thinking about the case?  Or you thought everything out before you killed Marsh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question hurts Rebecca -- it shows on her face.  She away from him.  A beat.  Dulaney thinks.  He feels bad fo asking such a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (she doesn't look at him) Rebecca -- I'm sorry.  Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand.  She slowly looks at him and smiles. points to the tea service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar or honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts a PLASTIC BOTTLE of HONEY and starts to pour it a cup.  She stops and smiles seductively at Dulaney, then her bathrobe and slowly draws a liquid line with it along thigh.  She reaches out -- grabs him by the hair and gent pulls him forward.  He kisses her knee and slowly runs hi tongue along her thigh, following the trail upwards.  She arches her back -- closes her eyes -- breathes deeply fro pleasure of his touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  The door opens -- light from the hall streaks into room.  Sharon is asleep.  Dulaney enters quietly.  He wat her.  He looks over at the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PHOTOGRAPH of Dulaney and Sharon on vacation.  Dulaney carrying her on a beach.  He is wearing a LARGE SOMBRERO. are both laughing. Dulaney looks back at Sharon.  He is a man lost within hi He walks to the bathroom.  Sharon opens her eyes and star him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Court is in session.  Cardenas stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State calls Doctor Alan Paley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Paley stands and walks towards the witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: CARDENAS AND PALEY
dialogues.text: Paley has been sworn in.  Cardenas examines him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you meet Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a dinner party -- about eight months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see her again after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What eventually happened to your relationship with Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stopped seeing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I realized that she wasn't interested in me.  She was just trying to get information out of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said that she was working on a novel and she wanted to know what kinds of drugs would be harmful to someone with a bad heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHISPERS from the crowd fill the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you suggest any?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- Insulin and others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said that those weren't any good -- because their use would be detected and the police would know the victim had been poisoned.  She wanted to know if there was a drug that would induce a heart attack but could also be used to enhance a sexual high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And what did you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More GASPS from the crowd.  Rebecca's remains calm, but h eyes glare at Paley hatefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dulaney) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas sits down.  Dulaney approaches Paley with a smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Paley, where were you the last time you saw Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had dinner at a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true that later that night you tried to force yourself on Miss Lawson in the parking lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't grab her and try to kiss her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If necessary I can bring in the valet parking attendant and two customers who witnessed the occurrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paley thinks for a moment.  He is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- as I remember it, we had an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the argument was about the fact that you wanted to be romantically involved and she did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after that didn't you continuously harass Miss Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney walks back to his desk and removes a TAPE PLAYER cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, this is a tape from Miss Lawson's answering machine.  I would like to play it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection.  Your Honor, we don't know where this tape is from.  Who made it -- or under what circumstances it was made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulaney takes out two pieces of PAPER and approaches the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are reports from two independent audio labs.  They each state that the voices were recorded over the phone and that no alterations have been made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts a bottle of white vinegar and holds it over his He tenses as she pours it on his chest.  -- then relaxes he realizes it's water.  He breathes a SIGH of relief.

dialogues.text: You see how life is, Frank?  We judge things.  We look at things from the outside and assume we know what's on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Rebecca moves her head to his chest -- kissi burns softly while her fingers caress lightly over his st She gradually moves her head down -- lower -- and lower.

dialogues.text: he stares at the ceiling -- his mind a maze of confusion. the power of her touch fills him -- overpowering him.  Hi close.  The pain that only moments ago filled his body is replaced with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late.  Dulaney enters quietly and heads for the stai LIGHT comes on.  Sharon is sitting on the couch waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTER CRAWFORD is on the stand.  She is a BLACK WOMAN in thirties -- thin and tired-looking, although we get the impression she once was pretty.  She is dressed in what i obviously her Sunday dress.  Cardenas questions her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Crawford, you were Mr. Marsh's maid for nine years?

dialogues.text: What did they argue about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name it -- they argued about it. Mr. Marsh tried his best to keep her happy -- but it seemed that no matter what he did it was never enough for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they argue the day before he died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- he died on a Sunday and I have the weekends off -- but they were ripping at each other with both barrels Friday afternoon.

dialogues.text: What was the nature of the argument?

dialogues.text: Dulaney jots down a note.  Cardenas continues.

dialogues.text: Did you ever see Mr. Marsh use cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dulaney) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardenas sits down.  Dulaney approaches Ester with a smil

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I fail to see what Mrs Crawford's educational background has to do with this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Objection, Your Honor.  The fact that Mrs. Crawford heard Mr. Troxell reconstruct her sentence and decided to rephrase her words in a more intelligent manner for the court doesn't mean the incident never happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't know what it's like where Mrs. Crawford comes from -- but I do.  I came from a neighborhood just like hers.  This is a whole other world for her.  She's a poor working woman who has been thrust into a room full of highly educated and mostly unsympathetic people.  So, she puts on her best dress, fixes her hair and tries to present herself as intelligently as possible. (beat) Being poor and having pride is not a crime, Mr. Dulaney -- and before you attempt to impeach another witness' testimony in my courtroom -- your foundations better be based on something other than semantics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

The PICTURE LASTS only about five seco We see Rebecca from the back as she straddles Marsh, grin up and down on the bed -- her hair flowing down her back. Marsh raises his hand.  His WRIST IS IN A CAST.  She turn head to the side and as she does we see that it is not Re -- but Joanne Braslow.  The Tape clicks off. Dulaney stares at the blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

He tries to contro surprise from the eyes of the jury, but he can't.  He sta ahead with a blank expression as he listens to the rest o testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This strikes a chord with Dulaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: What would she do that made it hard to resist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a woman who is very much aware of her own sexuality.  Sometimes I felt she could read my mind.  It was uncanny how she knew exactly what I wanted.  A few nights before my heart surgery Rebecca woke me.  She had handcuffed me to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a few SNICKERS from the crowd.  Dulaney is thin about the familiarity of Roston's testimony.  Judge Burnh BANGS his GAVEL.  The crowd becomes silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me that tonight we were going to open new doors.  I asked her to stop -- to take off the handcuffs, but she wouldn't listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roston is clearly uncomfortable having to relate this par his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roston I know this is difficult for you, but it's important you tell the court what she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she was going to fuck me like I've never been fucked before.

dialogues.text: Due to the sensitive nature of this witness' testimony and the inability of the spectators to allow him to complete it, I am clearing the courtroom.
